Bankey, G.0.secretary. so(This Document is the Property of Eis Britannic-SECRET-CABINET 63 (24).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet,held at 10, Downing Street, S.W. 1, onMONDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1924, at 12 Noon.EGYPT.m mi pm mBritishPolicy in.(previous reference:Cabinet 62(24).)q 8 xThe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, forthe benefit of those members who had not been ableto attend, briefly surrimrised the events whioh had led to the hastily summoned Meeting of the Cabineton Saturday, November 22nd. He then explained thatsome two hours after the despatch of the communication to the Egyptian Government approved by the Cabinet(No.226 to Lord Alleriby), information had beenreoeived that Lord Allenby had acted in advance ofthe Cabinet's instructions and had made two communi-indications to the Egyptian Government (Lord AllenbyNo.385) based on his earlier draft (Lord AllenbyNo.381). With the concurrence of the Prime minister the Seoretary of State for Foreign Affairs had thencuirmoned such Cabinet Ministers as were available inLondon to confer with him, and as the result of thismeeting Mr Chamberlain had sent the following tele-gram: -flI cannot conceal my concern that youdid not wait to receive the decisionof the Cabinet which I had told you must examine and approve the deolara-tIon before it was presented, and Ishall be glad if you will explainmore fully your reasons. I do notat present understand the extreme urgency under which you acted. his majesty's Government feel bound to support you in the action that you have already taken in this emergency,but it may be necessary for themafter the immediate crisis is overto-re-state position in acoordancewith the terms of my telegram No. 226(of 22nd November)".With the aid of the subsequent telegrams which had passed between him and Lord Allenby (Lord Allenby'stelegrams Nos.385 to 395 inclusive, and 398;Foreign Office telegrams Nos. 235 to 239 inclusive),the Secretary of State then explained the presentposition.The Cabinet * who cordially endorsed the line taken by the Foreign Secretary, agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should approve the language held by Lord Allenby toKing Fuad, as reported in his telegram No.395 Xof November 23rd),but should, if necessary, make itclear to King Fuad that the stepsalready taken in the Sudan oouldnot be revoked, though the Govern-ment had no desire to abandon the condominium unless forced by egypt to do so. He should also emphasizethat the Government did not approve the shooting of hostages, and thatthis measure must not in any circumstances-stances be adopted. He should authorise Lord Allenby to show toMr Asquith (who was staying at theResidency in Cairo) the telegrams which had passed, arid to keep himfully informed:(b) That, in view of the difficulty in keeping Lord Allenby informed from day to day by telegram alone of theviews of His Majesty's Government,the Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs should inform the HighCommissioner that he proposed tostrengthen his Staff during thepresent emergency by placing at his disposal the services of Mr"N.M.Henderson, CM.G. , who would be ina position to explain the views ofHis Majesty's Government, and whom he would recommend to Lord Allenby'sentire confidence:(c) That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should inform LordAllenoy that the Government had decided to appoint a civilian asGovernor of the Sudan, and that the High Commissioner shouldrequest the King of Egypt, underthe Agreement relative to theFuture Administration of theSudan, January 19, 1899, toappoint the nominee of the BritishGovernment, namel^r, Sir GeoffreyArcher, K. C.M.G. (whose services the Secretary of State for theColonies was willing to make available for this purpose):(d) That the following Cabinst Committeeshould be set up to assist theSecretary of State for ForeignAffairs on any natter he might wish to discuss with his colleaguesduring the present crisis:-The Prime Minister,The Lord President of the Council,The Chancellor of the Exchequer,The Secretary of State for the Colonies,The Secretary of State' for War,The Secretary of State for India,The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster,The Secretary to the Cabinet(or Senior Assistant * secretaries,Secretary) ^Mr J. The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs explained that the Conference had been summoned at short notice on a matter of great urgency. A telegram had been received from Lord Allenby stating that hewas making to the Egyptian Government in the name ofHis Majesty's Government at 4.45 p. mi. that day thetwo communications set forth in his telegram No.381date6. November 21st. Lord Allenby explained that hewas acting before receiving Cabinet authority as theimmediate resignation of the Egyptian Prime Minister 'was probable. (foreign Office telegram No ..384, dated november 22nd).In the course of the meeting information wasreceived that Lord Allenby had added, to the first of the two documents the following demand:-3. ' "Henceforth forbid and vigorouslysuppress all popular politicaldemonstrations."The Conference discussed the situation which hadthus arisen and considered in detail the documentsas presented by the High Commissioner and theinstructions which the Cabinet earlier that' day had authorised the Secretary of State for foreign affairs to forward to Lord Allenby (Cabinet 62(24)).Sir William Tyrrell and Mr. J. Murray of theforeign Office were present- for a part of the conference to answer questions.The Conference were of the decided opinion:-That Lord Allenby had not been justifiedin acting in defiance of the expressinstructions of. the Secretary of Statefor foreign Affairs (last paragraph of telegram Ho.220 of November 21st), butthat any advantage that might now attach to the note as approved by the cabinet would. altogether be outweighed by theappearance of hesitation, and loss of prestige which would, be involved in4isavowring Lord Allenby's action by revoking a document which had alreadybeen communicated by our representative, andthat they had no option but to supportthe authority of Lord Allenby in dealingwith a critical situation.The Conference also approved:-The terms of the telegram which theSecretary of State for foreign affairs should send to Lord Allenby, and that the/Secretary of State for the Colonies should send to the Dominion Governments a telegram on the same lines.At the close of the Conference the Secretary of Statefor foreign Affairs. communicated'the foregoing to thePrime Minister by telephone and the Prime Minister expressed his agreement.Whit ehall.Gardens, S.W.1.,; 22nd November, 1924.
